channel.title: Lee Brownhill's Blog
channel.description: Recent content on Lee Brownhill's Blog

item.title: SQL Unit Testing Using tSQLt: Part 2
item.description:
Unit Testing Experts!

In the last post, we went through what unit testing is, at least when discussing it in the context of SQL Server. In addition to that, we discussed what benefits using the open-source framework tSQLt can bring. Of course, you have studied that post diligently and now we’re all unit testing experts, right? … hello?

item.title: SQL Unit Testing Using tSQLt: Part 1
item.description:
Unit…what now?

Other practitioners of code-slinging, such as .NET folks, have been unit testing their code for many moons now. We SQL folks, however, rarely seem to do this, at least in my experience. Several job roles ago, I had to use unit testing on a daily basis. It was heavily integrated into our workflow via the CI/CD pipelines we used

item.title: About
item.description:
Lee Brownhill is a SQL Server DBA with more years of experience than he cares to admit. Currently, he works as a Principal Cloud DBA at Cloud Rede, helping clients optimise their SQL workloads in both Azure and AWS. His passion lies in optimisation and automation within SQL Server, and he confesses that he will never tire of making things run faster.

His journey in IT began many moons ago in IT support, where he quickly became fascinated with his organisationâ€™s SQL Server. It didn’t take long to realise that he wanted to work with SQL Server and so, eventually started his journey as a Production DBA at a SaaS financial company. Realising he had a knack for making systems more efficient, he transitioned to a Developer DBA role, bridging the gap between Infrastructure DBAs and developers.
